Your mileage may vary, of course, but it seems to me that you’d have to be quite a cynic not to love a grid where two different answers fit equally well in the same square. You may be reminded of another puzzle that is the Platonic Ideal of this technique, which is the 1996 BOB DOLE/CLINTON wonder that hedged its bets by allowing either side as the winner of the presidential election.

lead_paragraph: BITCOIN enthusiasts may want to study a satirical etching, published in 1792, that is now in a collection at London’s National Portrait Gallery. In one half, titled “French Liberty,” an emaciated French revolutionary gnaws on raw onions. In the other, “British Slavery,” a corpulent Englishman feasts on a giant slab of meat. The etching’s message — that a revolution is a farce if it fails to provide the basics — hangs uneasily over the world of virtual currencies.

abstract: The company implemented numerous growth strategies, but sales fell flat. The owners even stopped taking salaries,
snippet: The company implemented numerous growth strategies, but sales fell flat. The owners even stopped taking salaries,
lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about Jimmy Beans Wool, an online yarn and fabric retailer with a brick-and-mortar store in Reno, Nev. abstract: Medicare said that it planned to make available detailed information on what it pays individual physicians as soon as next week, despite the long-term resistance by the American Medical Association.
snippet: Medicare said that it planned to make available detailed information on what it pays individual physicians as soon as next week, despite the long-term resistance by the American Medical Association.
lead_paragraph: Medicare said on Wednesday that it planned to make available to consumers and others detailed information on what it pays individual physicians as soon as next week, despite the long-term resistance by the American Medical Association and other groups. The information will include data on the $77 billion paid by Medicare in 2012 to more than 880,000 health care professionals for 6,000 types of services and procedures. Patient information will remain private. “Data like these can shine a light on how care is delivered in the Medicare program,” said Jonathan Blum, principal deputy administrator at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, in a blog post. “They can help consumers compare the services provided and payments received by individual health care providers. Businesses and consumers alike can use these data to drive decision-making and reward quality, cost-effective care.” Medicare, the federal insurance program for the elderly, was prevented from releasing information on individual physicians until a ruling last year by a federal judge in Florida. In a statement issued by the A.M.A., the medical group raised concerns that Medicare’s broad release of the payment information could “mislead the public” and recommended that doctors be allowed to review and correct any information before it was made public.

headline.main: Medicare to Share Information on Pay for Physicians

abstract: The settlement, covering years of environmental claims, was at the low end of a court-defined range and ends a messy legal wrangle for Anadarko and its Kerr-McGee subsidiary, Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews writes.

lead_paragraph: Stock investors seem to have a firm grip on Anadarko Petroleum’s toxic waste settlement. The record $5.15 billion settlement on Thursday, covering years of environmental claims, was at the low end of a court-defined range, which had a midpoint of $9.8 billion. The 15 percent jump in the oil company’s market capitalization after the settlement was announced is mostly explained by those numbers. And it brings Anadarko’s 12-month stock performance nearly back in line with the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index after a bumpy ride.

headline.main: Investors Return to Anadarko After Record $5.1 Billion Settlement

abstract: The challenge of big data software tools to traditional data software companies is not that the new technology will be a direct replacement for the old. But big-data software like Hadoop is a formidable threat to the economics of incumbents. A look at Teradata, a leader in data warehouse software, and its announcements this week, shows the challenge and how an incumbent is responding.
snippet: The challenge of big data software tools to traditional data software companies is not that the new technology will be a direct replacement for the old. But big-data software like Hadoop is a formidable threat to the economics of incumbents. A loo...
lead_paragraph: Scott Gnau, president of Teradata Labs, seemed a little irritated by all the attention being showered on the big data marketplace. Big-data exuberance has surged with the recent news about how much money was raised by Cloudera, the frontrunner among start-ups distributing Hadoop, open-source software used for storing and parsing huge volumes of data. The total — mainly from Intel, but also venture capital firms — was $900 million, putting a value of $4.1 billion on the young company.

headline.main: The Big Data Challenge to Legacy Data Management Companies

abstract: High-frequency trading firms’ methods do not fit comfortably into any of the typical theories of securities fraud that have been used to pursue misconduct, Peter J. Henning writes in his White Collar Watch column.
snippet: High-frequency trading firms’ methods do not fit comfortably into any of the typical theories of securities fraud that have been used to pursue misconduct, Peter J. Henning writes in his White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Words like “rigged” and “scam,” which have been used to describe how high-frequency trading firms make money in the markets, usually indicate something illegal has occurred. The attorney general, Eric H. Holder Jr., added to that perception when he confirmed at a congressional hearing on Friday that the Justice Department was investigating high-frequency trading “to determine whether it violates insider trading laws.”

headline.main: High-Frequency Trading Falls in the Cracks of Criminal Law

abstract: How can you design a set of three dice that work like the rock-paper-scissors game?
snippet: How can you design a set of three dice that work like the rock-paper-scissors game?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week is about a tricky kind of relationship — one that’s a bit counterintuitive. Normally, when we compare several things, we expect something like the following: your friend Agnes weighs more than Beatrice, and Beatrice weighs more than Clarissa, then we’d expect Agnes to outweigh Clarissa. This makes sense. This kind of relationship would also work for heights, ages, and other single-dimension measures. This also works for containers: a dime is in a small pouch in Clarissa’s purse, so the dime is in the purse.

headline.main: Tricky Dice

abstract: Setting fundamental goals, not micromanaging finances, can provide structure without rigidity, a financial planner writes.
snippet: Setting fundamental goals, not micromanaging finances, can provide structure without rigidity, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: When we think of financial planning, we naturally focus on the future. We start by getting really clear about where we are today, then we spend time thinking about where we want to be 10, 20 or even 30 years from now. Part of the process includes deciding how much we’ll want to spend, when we’ll want to spend it and how much we can save. Someone has to decide when the plan will end, too, and estimate a year of death, perhaps for two people.

headline.main: With Planning Out of the Way, Time to Enjoy the Moment

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE Keystone XL pipeline is a great political symbol. The proposed 1,700-mile pipeline, which would carry 830,000 barrels daily of carbon-heavy crude from Canada’s Alberta oil sands to Gulf Coast refineries, has galvanized environmental activists, who call it a litmus test for President Obama’s commitment to fighting climate change. It is a political weapon against Mr. Obama for Republicans, who call it a symbol of job creation and energy security. It has motivated liberal donors, led by the California billionaire Tom Steyer, who has personally urged Mr. Obama to reject the pipeline.

headline.main: Keystone Pipeline May Be Big, but This Is Bigger

snippet: The Supreme Court battle over Aereo could cast a pall over the cloud computing industry. For consumers, though, Aereo is too inefficient to become a useful service.
lead_paragraph: The best way to think about Aereo, the company at the center of this week’s Supreme Court battle over the future of computing, is as an example of legal performance art. Aereo is based entirely on a legalistic leap of faith: If it’s legal to set up an antenna and record a TV show at your own house, which it is, shouldn’t it also be legal to rent an antenna and server space at a big data center, and then stream the show over the Internet to your computer, tablet or set-top box?

abstract: A judge ruled Friday that The Philadelphia Inquirer, Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com would be sold at an auction open only to its existing owners.
snippet: A judge ruled Friday that The Philadelphia Inquirer, Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com would be sold at an auction open only to its existing owners.
lead_paragraph: A judge ruled Friday that The Philadelphia Inquirer, Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com would be sold at an auction open only to its existing owners. It is the latest legal milestone in a battle between the wealthy, politically connected men who formed a partnerships to buy the publications in 2012, but have since fallen out over accusations of inappropriate influence exerted on the newsroom, and thrown them into turmoil. The ruling, by Delaware Chancery Court Judge Donald F. Parsons, was seen as a victory for one of the men, George E. Norcross III, a businessman and Democratic power broker in New Jersey. Another of the owners, Lewis Katz, the former owner of the New Jersey Nets, had fought for a public sale open to anyone. Mr. Norcross was accused of installing his daughter at the head of Philly.com and of influencing the dismissal of The Inquirer’s editor, William K. Marimow. He has denied any inappropriate behavior.

headline.main: Philadelphia Newspapers to Be Sold to Insiders

lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — When people ask what I do for a living, I always make sure to tell them specifically that I write a blog for the web version of The New York Times. It’s fun to watch the range of reactions cross their faces, because most people still think of The Times in term of the print newspaper, and not everyone is aware of our online presence. And while I thank the universe every day that print is still alive and somewhat well, The Times has come a very long way in terms of presenting the news online in ways that I think are both innovative and well-designed.
